title: Uber to expand its trucking freight service to Canada
text:
Like its ride-hailing app, the service will connect companies that need to have goods shipped with available truck drivers. Any trucking company can register. Uber’s first Canadian delivery partners include Martin Brower, which delivers for McDonald’s and other restaurant chains. The service will launch first in Quebec and Ontario, and will include domestic shipments and those to and from the U.S. (Globe and Mail)

Talking point: Uber has already launched the service in the U.S., Germany and the Netherlands, the result of a US$200-million investment. It’s part of a broader strategy to diversify its business into sectors like food delivery and electric scooters as the ride-hailing market becomes increasingly crowded. Canada has been a testbed for many of Uber’s new endeavors, including Uber Eats, which became the company’s fastest-growing division after it launched in Toronto. Canada’s $39-billion trucking market could be another promising opportunity for a company still establishing its plan to profitability.
